title: Introduction
instruction: Select Menu to continue.
Select Next to continue.
body:
Introduction

Course guide

This module will explain to you what this course is about. It will provide some background to managing information securely, and will give details of what you’ll learn as a result of completing all the modules.

You must view all the information on each screen before you are able to progress through the course.

Introduction

Staying alert

We all have a responsibility to manage information securely. But how easy is it to break a policy or even worse the law? Put yourself in the shoes of these people and consider how you would have reacted or behaved in these situations.

Click on the arrow to view the scenarios below then click Next to continue.

_items.body: Jaxon works in a local housing office but still has access to a children services system due to his previous role.
A member of the public is in dispute with their local leisure centre and wants to know what information they have.
Jerome types up minutes from a family conference but accidently sends them to the wrong recipients.
A group of protestors are ejected from the local one stop and film the process.
A member of the public records a meeting between themselves and a member of staff.
John is processing a blue badge application and is unexpectedly called away.
Angie receives an email from her managers personal email account asking her to change some payment details.
Ravi becomes the victim of cyber crime.
Ameera and Finlay have a meeting in a busy café to discuss a number of work related matters

body:
Introduction

Points to remember

We all have a personal responsibility for managing the information we work with securely. However, we’re all busy and it’s easy to make mistakes.

The mistakes we make can cause serious issues for our customers and the organisation. We’ll look at some of these implications later in the course. For now, here are some important things that will help you apply good practice in your day-to-day work.

And remember, Information is Everybody’s Business.

Although this training concentrates mainly on personal information, it’s important to remember that the organisation handles lots of other sorts of information. It’s important to make sure that we handle all information safely and appropriately.
instruction: Select each option to see more.

items.feedbackbody: Personal informationYou should look after our customers’ personal information just as you would if it were about people you know. You wouldn’t like to see personal information about your friends and family publicly available so you should treat other people’s information with the same respect.

Handling informationBe careful when you’re handling information. Carelessness is a major cause of issues, so it’s important that you concentrate when you’re handling information and not let distractions cause you to misplace or divulge sensitive information. The key to handling information successfully is to be aware of the sensitivity of the information you handle at all times and treat it accordingly.
If in doubtIf you’re not sure what to do or need any advice you should contact your Information Governance Officer.

instruction: Select Next to continue or the menu icon to return to the menu.
body:
Introduction

About the course

We’ve started to identify your role in managing information responsibly. This course will help you develop a better understanding of the procedures you should follow.

By the end of the course you’ll be able to:

  • Explain what information security is and why information must be kept secure.
  • Know about the law relating to managing information correctly and understand the implications for breaching the law.
  • Apply the organisation’s information governance policies and procedures.
  • Adopt the correct behaviours to keep information secure inside and outside of work.

It should take you approximately 40 minutes to complete the course and at the end there will be a quiz for you to check what you know about effectively managing information.

instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
What does the law say?

Introduction to the law

You need to have some knowledge about two key pieces of law relating to handling information.

  • The Freedom of Information Act 2000 gives individuals and organisations the right to request information from publicly funded bodies.
  • Data protection law exists to protect people’s personal information and provide individuals with rights over their data.

You’ll learn more about these laws later.

What does the law say?

What’s the best response?

Jaxon Price works in the local housing office advising members of the public on their rents and provides general housing advice.
instruction: Select each image to see more.

items.feedbackbody: Sensitive informationAdditionally, Jaxon previously worked in Children’s Social Care, who are currently involved with a member of his family. Jaxon decides to check on the progress of the referral, then discloses the information to the family member.
Just checkingJaxon is curious to know if his ex-partner is up to date on his rent account. Jaxson check’s up on his partner’s situation using the housing system.

body:
What does the law say?

What went wrong?

Think about the scenario you’ve just seen and consider whether you think Jaxon has broken any laws through his actions.
instruction: Select an option from each of the dropdown lists. Then select Submit.

_items.text: Should Jaxon be looking at information on the Children's case management system?

_options.text: It’s OK to view the information as an employee of the organisation
It’s OK to view the information for personal use

_items.text: As Jaxon still works for the organisation, should he still have access to the Children's information in his new role?

_options.text: Jaxon still works for the organisation so is OK to have access and view the information
Jaxon's access to the children's case management system should be removed when he moved to his new role
It’s OK for Jaxon to have access but not to view the information on the Childrens case management system

_items.text: Has Jaxon broken any laws by checking his ex-partner’s rent account status?

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. Under no circumstances should Jaxson look for information he doesn't require to do his job, as this is potentially a criminal offence under Data Protection law.
Furthermore, Jaxon’s access to the Children’s case management system should have been removed immediately when he left his previous role. It is usually the responsibility of the current and previous line manager to ensure this happens; refer to your organisations appropriate policies and procedures.
Additionally, it is Jaxon’s responsibility to ensure he only has access to the information he requires to do his current role.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. Under no circumstances should Jaxon look for information he doesn't require to do his job, as this is potentially a criminal offence under Data Protection law.
Furthermore, Jaxson’s access to the children’s case management system should have been removed immediately when he left his previous role.
It is usually the responsibility of the current and previous line manager to ensure this happens; refer to your organisations appropriate policies and procedures.
Additionally, it is Jaxon’s responsibility to ensure he only has access to the information he requires to do his current role.

body:
What does the law say?

What you need to know

Whilst you don’t need to know the law in detail, you do need a good understanding of what’s important and what it means to your role at your organisation.

If you’re not sure whether you’re doing the right things when you collect or use personal information you should talk to your Information Governance Officer.
instruction: Select each option to see more.
instructionFinal: Select Next to continue or the menu icon to return to the menu.

items.feedbackbody:
Freedom of Information Act 2000The Freedom of Information Act allows individuals or other organisations to ask public bodies to release information. Requests need to be submitted in writing and we should aim to provide information for every request within 20 working days.

If we don’t comply with the Freedom of information Act, not only can it cause damage to the organisation’s reputation and public trust, the Information Commissioner can take action against the organisation.

If there’s a request for environmental information there are slightly different rules covered by the Environmental Information Regulation.

Like the FOIA, anyone has the right to make a request. However, one important difference is that these can be made verbally as well as in writing. Therefore consideration needs to be given as to what type of request it is. If in doubt contact your Information Governance Officer.

Your roleYour Information Governance Officer might ask you for information to respond to a Subject Access request (SAR), to correct or complete someone’s data or to decide if information is still needed. They may also need to talk to you about the format the information needs to be in, to justify why we are using the data or whether there is any automated decision–making.

You may have to stop using data temporarily and to make a note in the system if someone challenges the accuracy of their data or objects to the organisation using their data. It would be a criminal offence if you destroyed, hid, erased or blocked data to stop it being disclosed to someone in response to a SAR, or a data portability request, or an FOI request.

To find out more information about SARs click here.

Data Protection LawData Protection law exists to protect the privacy of individuals. It provides us with rules that we need to follow to manage the personal information of our staff and customers properly.

Action can be taken against organisations if they breach Data Protection law and fines can be issued if the breaches are serious.

You could be prosecuted and fined if you were found to have deliberately obtained or disclosed personal data (including accessing someone else’s personal data) without the organisation’s consent. Furthermore, this could lead to disciplinary action within your organisation.

The principlesThere are six principles in the law that we all need to abide by when handling personal data and which the organisation must be able to demonstrate compliance with. We must ensure that personal data is:

  1. Used lawfully, fairly and transparently.
  2. Collected for specific, explicit and legitimate purposes, and not used for any incompatible purpose.
  3. Adequate, relevant and limited to what’s needed.
  4. Accurate and where necessary kept up to date.
  5. Kept in a way which identifies individuals for no longer than necessary.
  6. Used and kept securely.

Individuals’ rightsIndividuals (whether they’re employees or customers) have a number of rights under the Data Protection law, and we need to be able to demonstrate how we observe those rights, which include:

  • The right to know what information is held about them and to request their personal information. This is known as a Subject Access Request (SAR).
  • The right to get their data corrected or completed, if need be.
  • The right to get their data erased (right to be forgotten), for example if their data isn’t needed any more.
  • The right to object on personal grounds to the organisation using their data, and if they use it the organisation has to show that this use is justified.
  • Individuals have the right to get the use of their data restricted, for example while they challenge the accuracy of their data or while they object to the organisation using their data.
  • The organisation usually has to tell people who it’s disclosed data to, if there is any correction or erasure of data, or restriction on using data.
  • They have the right to get their data in a standard format, and to send it to someone else.
  • They have the right not to have a decision made about them which is based just on automatic processing.

All of the above may be subject to exceptions that would need to be considered on a case by case basis.

If you are contacted by someone who wants to exercise these rights, you must contact your Information Governance Officer.

body:
Creating and storing information

Mistakes can happen

Now that you have some understanding of the law let’s look at what needs to happen when you create and store information by considering this scenario.

Here’s some information about Wayne Ford. Wayne is banned from his local leisure centre for 6 months for an assault at the centre. During this time Wayne turns up at the Leisure centre reception demanding some information.

Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body: Wayne's request for informationWayne disputes his ban and thinks the leisure centre is holding case notes about him. He wants the information about himself corrected and he objects to the leisure centre stating he’s aggressive.
Wayne's right to be forgotten?Additionally, Wayne wants the letter detailing the ban about himself deleted due to his right to be forgotten and doesn’t want his personal trainer to know.
Request not to share informationWayne feels victimised and puts a freedom of information request asking for the number of people banned from his leisure centre.

body:
Creating and storing information

What Happens Next?

Think about the scenario you’ve just seen and consider what Wayne is entitled to. Then decide which of the following are true and which are false.
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: Wayne can have the letter about his ban deleted from his file.
Wayne can successfully request his aggressive behaviour is corrected on any case notes.
Wayne can ensure his personal trainer is not allowed to know about his aggressive behaviour.
Wayne is entitled to request information about the number of people who have been banned from the leisure centre

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. The ‘right to be forgotten’ doesn’t apply here because assault is very serious and the ban was recent so it’s necessary for the Housing Office to keep information about this so that the tenancy can be managed safely.

Wayne could object to the leisure centre using his information, but his privacy rights are outweighed by the leisure centre’s need to manage the health and safely of the staff and members of the public.

Wayne’s request for general information held by a public body is a Freedom of Information request.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. The ‘right to be forgotten’ doesn’t apply here because assault is very serious and the ban was recent so it’s necessary for the Housing Office to keep information about this so that the tenancy can be managed safely.

Wayne could object to the leisure centre using his information, but his privacy rights are outweighed by the leisure centre’s need to manage the health and safely of the staff and members of the public.

Wayne’s request for general information held by a public body is a Freedom of Information request.

instruction: Select each tab to see more.
body:
Creating and storing information

Accuracy is the best policy

The quality of our information will have a direct impact on the quality of the service we provide to our customers so you need to make sure the information you create and collect is accurate.

_items.title: What do I need to consider when I’m creating information?
_items.body:
When you create a document it should be accurate and fit for purpose, and it helps if you get it right first time rather than needing to correct errors later.

You should follow the organisation’s standards, formats and templates, and record data and information as soon after obtaining it as possible. Good data quality means good customer service, fewer complaints, fewer requests for correction and less potential for any chance of an embarrassing situation with a customer.

_items.title: What’s important when I’m collecting information?
_items.body:
If you work in a service where you collect personal information you must tell people what we’re going to do with their information and how they can exercise their rights. This should be done by adding a privacy notice to the documents the customer needs to complete.

You mustn’t mislead people about what we’re going to do with their details and it may be necessary to get their permission to share them at a later date. We always need to be fair about how we use someone’s personal data and you must not collect more information than you need.

_items.title: How should I store information correctly?
_items.body:
Make sure you know where to put information in the right place, whether it’s electronic or paper. Your colleagues may need to find the information you’ve created.

You need to name your files in the right way, use appropriate version control so it’s clear which version is the latest, and know where to save computer files so that others can easily find them. You must also be careful to store paper records in the right place.

instruction: Select the correct answers. Then select Submit.
body:
Creating and storing information

Storing information

Now you understand how important it is to create and collect accurate information, let’s think about how it should be protected and stored.

Jerome Clement works for Children’s services. Consider the following situation and decide if he behaves
Jerome has typed up the minutes for two separate family group conferences, which the families have requested by post.

After printing the Family conference minutes for the Smith and Jones families he attaches the wrong covering letter to the conference minutes which results in them being posted to the wrong families.

_items.text: Jerome should have checked that the minutes and the corresponding letters matched up before posting them out
It’s not a big issue that the information has gone to the wrong address, the person who receives it will probably return it
By being careless about the information he’s collected Jerome is in breach of Data Protection law

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. Information going to the wrong address could lead to someone misusing the information. Furthermore, due to the sensitive content Jerome should ensure his work is peer checked to ensure the minutes are going to the right address. You can’t make the assumption that it will be returned, and Jerome has breached Data Protection law by being careless with personal information.

_incorrect.final:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. Information going to the wrong address could lead to someone misusing the information. Furthermore, due to the sensitive content Jerome should ensure his work is peer checked to ensure the minutes are going to the right address. You can’t make the assumption that it will be returned, and Jerome has breached Data Protection law by being careless with personal information.

instruction: Select the correct answer. Then select Submit.
body:
Creating and storing information

Storing information

A group of protesters come into a busy one stop centre. They go on to threaten security staff, as well as Amelia on reception, causing a disturbance. They are asked to leave due to their threatening behaviour towards Amelia and eventually security escorts them off the premises. The protestors ask for the one stop centre’s CCTV footage on the basis that they claim they were assaulted.

The protest group are known for publishing images on social media, which in the past have resulted in assaults and attacks on individuals and therefore the one stop manager is apprehensive in the footage being released.

_items.text: The group of protestors have a right to request the CCTV  footage
Further to the request for information the organisation are ok to release all CCTV images
The organisation have a right to refuse disclosing the CCTV footage to the protestors as the safety of the staff member outweighs the rights of the requestors

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. Although the protestors are within in their rights to request the CCTV footage the one stop manager cannot automatically release the footage. It can be released in some cases if there is a crime or for court proceedings. This request should come via Information Governance.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. Although the protestors are within in their rights to request the CCTV footage the one stop manager cannot automatically release the footage. It can be released in some cases if there is a crime or for court proceedings. This request should come via Information Governance.

instruction: Select the correct answer. Then select Submit.
body:
Creating and storing information

Storing information

Whilst John is processing a request for a disability parking badge on his computer a new colleague on the other side of the office calls him over asking for help, John stops what he is doing and goes straight across to his colleague, leaving his computer unlocked.

John, then comes back to his desk and posts the blue badge application to the customer. A few weeks later John receives a call from the customer complaining he still hasn’t received his blue badge. On checking the system it appears the customers address was not updated with their new details when he informed the organisation over a month ago.

What statements are right and which are wrong?

_items.text: John should have gone over straight away to his colleague even though he was halfway through processing the application and his computer was unlocked, he works in an office with trusted colleagues
He should tell the colleague he’d be over once he has saved his work in the right place and locked his computer
He should turn off his computer so that no-one can see what he’s working on
The system should have been updated with the correct address when the customer called over a month ago

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. The information he’s working on needs to be saved in the correct place and his computer should be locked before he leaves his desk. Additionally, customer details must be updated immediately as this can affect service provision, decisions and can provide a poor experience for the customer.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. The information he’s working on needs to be saved in the correct place and his computer should be locked before he leaves his desk. Additionally, customer details must be updated immediately as this can affect service provision, decisions and can provide a poor experience for the customer.

instruction: Select the correct answers. Then select Submit.
body:
Creating and storing information

Storing information

Sunil, of the council's anti-social behaviour team has an interview with a member of the public, Leah Thawn in a organisation meeting room.

Leah is recording the interview for her personal record. After the meeting Leah goes on to publish the interview to social media which also contains offensive comments about Sunil.

_items.text: Leah is allowed to record the meeting for her personal use
Leah is allowed to publish the images to a wide audience on social media
The organisation is within their rights to report Leah to the Information Commissioners Office, as Leah is acting as the data controller

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s correct. Leah is within her rights to record the meeting for her own personal use. Once that recording is put on to social media, Leah becomes the Data Controller of the information and is under the same legal responsibility and accountability as any organisation which collects and processes personal information. The organisation is within its rights to report Leah to the ICO for inappropriately publishing the information to social media.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That's not right. Leah is within her rights to record the meeting for her own personal use. Once that recording is put on to social media, Leah becomes the ‘Data Controller’ of the information and is under the same legal responsibility and accountability as any organisation which collects and processes personal information. The organisation is within its rights to report Leah to the ICO for inappropriately publishing the information to social media.

body:
Creating and storing information

Keeping information secure

Storing information in the right place is important to make sure it is secure and that the right people can access it whenever they need to. The Data Protection law states that only people who need to see personal data should be able to access it and that we shouldn’t keep information for longer than is necessary.

You have a responsibility for making sure that the information you handle is secure and is only seen by people who are authorised to do so.

In offices where sensitive information is stored you must follow the correct signing in procedures and wear your organisation's ID badge at all times. That way we always know who has access to the data we hold.

Your Information Governance Officer can help you if you’re not sure about the storage of information.

Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body:
Storing paper documentsDocuments containing personal or sensitive information should be stored securely.

Speak to your Information Governance Officer about what to do with documents which need to be held for a long period.

Information on computersDifferent areas of the computer system are accessible to different people, it’s therefore important that you store documents on the correct drive.

You must make sure that information is stored in such a way as to make sure that only colleagues who need to see certain information have access to it.

Locking your screenYou should always lock your screen whenever you leave your desk, even if it’s only for a short time. This applies if you’re in the office or working at home (using a desk PC or a laptop). You can do this by pressing the Windows key+L on your keyboard.

You need to log off when you leave your desk for long periods.

Managing your work areasYou should make sure your desk is clear of paper at the end of the day, and that you tidy away documents when you’re away from your desk for more than a brief period, including lunchtime and meetings. You should never leave documents containing personal information on your desk when you’re away from it.

It’s your responsibility to ensure that documents on your desk aren’t visible to visitors, members of the public or colleagues who aren’t authorised to see them.

Locking drawersIf you handle information that’s personal or sensitive you need to be able to store this securely, and it should only be seen by people authorised to do so. Speak to your manager for advice on how your team stores paper information securely.

body:
Sharing and disposing of information

To share or not to share?

You’ve seen the procedures for creating and storing information. Sometimes we need to share information with other people. The decision about whether it’s appropriate to share personal or sensitive information is an important one.

Let’s start by looking at some of the dilemmas facing Children’s social worker Kayla during a particularly busy Monday morning.

During the morning she receives several requests from other departments to share information about some of her cases.

Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body:
Concerns over the impact on privacyThe first request comes from a different area of the organisation that she has not dealt with before. Kayla’s concerned about the impact sharing this information will have on the privacy of the young person whose information it is. Find out more about consent here.

She calls the Information Governance Officer to get advice that will help her assess whether providing the information would be appropriate.

Keep it relevant for the purposeKayla receives a second request for information. She thinks the department has asked for more information than they need.

She decides to check with her line manager and the Information Governance Officer before she releases the information.

Handling an urgent requestShe then receives a call requesting urgent information connected to a safeguarding case. The situation is an emergency so she decides to provide the information.

We will look at this in more detail later in the course.

Files with incomplete/inaccurate dataA request has come in for details about an individual from a file that Kayla knows is not up to date. The person has moved around, she cannot be certain the details of the address are correct and she knows that some of the individual’s circumstances have changed.

She explains this to the colleague who’s requested the information and decides to retain the file to update the details.

Being fair about sharing informationA colleague is requesting information about an individual that Kayla works closely with. She knows they have not been told that their personal information may be shared for the reason that her colleague requires it.

Kayla isn’t sure whether Data Protection laws allows the sharing of this information without the individual’s consent, she decides to check with her line manager and the Information Governance Officer.

Treating documents properlyWhile she is making a cup of coffee in the office kitchen, she notices some papers marked ‘Private and Confidential’ on a table.

She informs her manager and gives her the documents.

instruction: Select the three correct answers. Then select Submit.
body:
Sharing and disposing of information

Did she make the right decisions?

You’ve seen how Kayla dealt with the various requests for information but did she make the right decisions?

Consider Kayla’s decisions and select the three statements you think are correct.

_items.text: It’s never OK to pass on information without the person’s consent.
As it was a safeguarding matter she was right to release the details in this case.
Kayla followed the correct procedure when she discovered the confidential documents.
If personal information is required by another department in the organisation she doesn’t always need the person’s consent to share.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. She can release information in an emergency and speak to her line manager about it afterwards.
Sometimes it’s OK to share information without consent, although she was right to check.
She followed the correct procedure for reporting a potential security incident (finding the confidential documents) and people don’t always need to know why their information is being shared.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. She can release information in an emergency and speak to her line manager about it afterwards.
Sometimes it’s OK to share information without consent, although she was right to check.
She followed the correct procedure for reporting a potential security incident (finding the confidential documents) and people don’t always need to know why their information is being shared.

instruction: Select each tab to see more.
body:
Sharing and disposing of information

Emergency case

We know that one of the requests Kayla received related to a safeguarding case.

If her professional judgement is that the situation was a genuine emergency then she was right to release the information.

She also needs to inform her line manager as soon as possible.

_items.title: An unexpected need
_items.body: Sometimes an unexpected need to share someone’s personal data may arise – for example in an emergency situation or in an urgent safeguarding case.

_items.title: Using professional judgement
_items.body:
If, for example a Children’s or Adults’ Social Worker makes a decision to use or share information based on their professional judgment, by weighing up what might happen if the information is shared against what might happen if it isn’t, this will be legitimate under Data Protection law.

It may also be appropriate for other services to share information in emergency situations.

_items.title: Acting in the best interests
_items.body: It is very important that Data Protection law is not seen as a barrier to professionals acting in the best interests of children and adults, particularly where there is a risk of harm.

instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
Sharing and disposing of information

Using the post

Kayla handled all the requests for information well and was able to either email or speak to the people making the requests. However, sometimes you’ll need to share information by post and although that sounds straightforward it’s easy to make mistakes.

There are three key things to remember:

  1. Double check names and addresses to make sure it is being sent to the right address.
  2. Check that you are putting the correct information in the envelopes before sealing them.
  3. If you use the internal post envelopes make sure that you cross out the name of the previous addressee.

It is advisable and in certain services you must have the post peer checked before sending it.

Carrying out these procedures will mean that the right people will receive the right information.

instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
Sharing and disposing of information

How long is long enough?

We now know that there are some important rules about sharing information with others. There are also some important rules about how long we can keep personal information for.

Data Protection law is clear that we shouldn’t keep personal data for longer than is necessary. There are clear rules about how long information can be kept for and this is contained within in the organisation’s retention schedule.

If you need further assistance, please check with your Information Governance Officer. The retention schedule can be found on InSite and is a guide to help you apply the correct retention to documents.

instruction: Select each tab to see more.
instructionFinal: Select Next to continue or the menu icon to return to the menu.
body:
Sharing and disposing of information

Disposing of information

There are rules about how long we can keep information – we also have to be very careful how we dispose of it, particularly if it is of a personal or sensitive nature.

If you need help or advice about this you should ask your Information Governance Officer.

_items.title: Disposing of information securely
_items.body:
You must dispose of personal or sensitive information securely using the confidential waste bin, or by using a cross-cutting shredder.

You should use a lockable confidential waste bin, where made available.

_items.title: Returning documents for disposal
_items.body:
When working away from the office you must not dispose of any papers in an unsecure way at home or anywhere else.

You must return all hard copy documents to the office for appropriate disposal.

_items.title: Disposing of equipment
_items.body:
You must follow your organisation’s procedure for the disposal of computer equipment or storage media such as memory sticks, smart phones or DVDs.

DIS will arrange for the collection of the equipment and provide a ‘credit’ receipt which can be swapped for a reconditioned piece of equipment only if the item(s) to be disposed of is/are within the current council specification of device at the time of collection.

body:
Sharing and disposing of information

Module Recap

You’ve seen the procedures for creating and storing information. Sometimes we need to share information with other people. The decision about whether it’s appropriate to share personal or sensitive information is an important one.

Let’s start by looking at some of the dilemmas facing Children’s social worker Kayla during a particularly busy Monday morning.

During the morning she receives several requests from other departments to share information about some of her cases.

Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body:
Disposing of information securelyThe first request comes from a different area of the organisation that she has not dealt with before. Kayla’s concerned about the impact sharing this information will have on the privacy of the young person whose information it is. Find out more about consent here.

She calls the Information Governance Officer to get advice that will help her assess whether providing the information would be appropriate.

Keep it relevant for the purposeKayla receives a second request for information. She thinks the department has asked for more information than they need.

She decides to check with her line manager and the Information Governance Officer before she releases the information.

Handling an urgent requestShe then receives a call requesting urgent information connected to a safeguarding case. The situation is an emergency so she decides to provide the information.

We will look at this in more detail later in the course.

Files with incomplete/inaccurate dataA request has come in for details about an individual from a file that Kayla knows is not up to date. The person has moved around, she cannot be certain the details of the address are correct and she knows that some of the individual’s circumstances have changed.

She explains this to the colleague who’s requested the information and decides to retain the file to update the details.

Being fair about sharing informationA colleague is requesting information about an individual that Kayla works closely with. She knows they have not been told that their personal information may be shared for the reason that her colleague requires it.

Kayla isn’t sure whether Data Protection laws allows the sharing of this information without the individual’s consent, she decides to check with her line manager and the Information Governance Officer.

Treating documents properlyWhile she is making a cup of coffee in the office kitchen, she notices some papers marked ‘Private and Confidential’ on a table.

She informs her manager and gives her the documents.

instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
Using the system securely

Passwords, emails and the internet

We’ve covered earlier the steps you need to take to keep the information on your computer secure.

We’re now going to consider that further by looking at how you can best use passwords to safeguard the information on your computer. We’ll also look at how to use the email system responsibly, and see ‘dos’ and ‘don’ts’ for using the internet.

Using the system securely

What’s the word?

Let’s start by looking at some example passwords. Which of the following passwords do you think are strong and secure, and which are weak?

Be careful; how we view passwords has changed as cyber criminals become ever more sophisticated. You are now advised to follow the National Cyber Security Centre’s (NCSC) guidance which recommends using ordinary randomly selected words that you are likely to remember, for example musicbagpotato, and you must use at least 12 characters. Refer to your organisation’s policies and procedures for specific guidance on your password protocols.
instruction: Select an option from each of the dropdown lists. Then select Submit.

_items.text: Strong
Weak

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. Your password shouldn’t be easy to guess and not easily linked to you. Your password should be at least 12 characters long and consist of random words. This makes it harder for the computer to crack and easier for you to remember.

Let’s move on to see the rules you should apply when you create your password.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. Your password shouldn’t be easy to guess and not easily linked to you. Your password should be at least 12 characters long and consist of random words. This makes it harder for your password to be cracked and easier for you to remember.

Let’s move on to see the rules you should apply when you create your password.

displayTitle:
Using the system securely

Password rules
body: Here are some basic rules for selecting and using passwords based on NSCS guidance.
instruction: Click on each symbol to see more.
instructionFinal:
The key to creating a memorable password is to choose something that you can remember but is hard for the computer to decipher for instance the phrase Doorhorsehat.

Select Next to continue.

items.feedbackbody:
Do
  • Use at least 12 characters.
  • Choose random words that you will remember.
  • Use hyphens, spaces or underscores to separate words.

Don’t
  • Use common names, for example family names, names of pets, friends, co-workers or celebrities.
  • Use anything that could be easily guessed such as ‘password’ or 123456789.
  • Use favourite team names or band names.
  • Use department names or well-known words with numbers on the end such as ‘jamesbond007.
  • Write it down or share with anyone.

instruction: Select the two correct answers. Then select Submit.
body:
Using the system securely

Email Rules

As well as using secure passwords, you must also continue to use the computer system in a secure way, which includes using emails. Let’s think about how careful you are with emails by considering how Angie deals with the following situations.

Angie, a finance employee, receives an email from her manager’s home email account at 4pm on a Friday. The tone is urgent and insists she change the payment details for a customer immediately.

Angie changes the payment details on the purchase order as per her managers’ instructions and goes home without discussing it with anyone.

_items.text: Angie was right to change the payment details.
When receiving an emailed instruction or a telephone call from outside the organisation to request changes to payment details the requestor must be verified by other means.
When emailed instructions are received from outside the organisation, it is important to discuss this with your manager.
The details needed to be changed as the weekend approached and could not wait until Monday.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. There is a risk, that Angie’s manager’s personal email has been ‘hacked’, meaning someone else is in control of their account. A malicious person could be trying to trick you into assisting their fraudulent activity. By discussing with your manager, you are able to ascertain whether the instruction is valid. It’s always important to check, to ensure fraudulent attempts are thwarted.

Close this window and attempt the next question.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. There is a risk, that Angie’s manager’s personal email has been ‘hacked’, meaning someone else is in control of their account. A malicious person could be trying to trick you into assisting their fraudulent activity. By discussing with your manager, you are able to ascertain whether the instruction is valid. It’s always important to check, to ensure fraudulent attempts are thwarted.

Close this window and attempt the next question.

instruction: Select the two correct answers. Then select Submit.
body:
Angie sends an email to all the recipients of a funding grant application, including her line manager Sam Richards, when writing the email she ‘Cc’s in all individuals to save sending several emails. All those who receive the email can see all the recipients’ email addresses and as a result one of the recipients complains. In addition, there are two people with the name ‘Sam Richards’ on the organisation’s email address book. Angie sends the grant application to her personal Gmail account as she’s very busy and wants to review the information in detail after she leaves work.

Consider this scenario and select the two answers you think are correct.

_items.text: Angie was right to ‘Cc’ in all attendees when sending out an email.
When emailing more than one person Angie should choose the Bcc functionality.
Angie not has shared any personal details.
Angie has shared individuals private email addresses that are considered personal information, and the organisation would be in breach of the Data Protection law.
Angie is ok to send and keep the grant application on her home Gmail account.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. Private email addresses are considered personal data just like someone’s home address. By only using the ‘Cc’ option the email addresses remain visible to all. ‘Bcc’ hides the recipient’s email addresses from the other recipients. By sending the information to her home Gmail, Angie is in breach of the organisation's policies and procedures and puts the information outside the security of the organisation, making it potentially accessible from unsecured devices and by unauthorised individuals.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. Private email addresses are considered personal data just like someone’s home address. By only using the ‘Cc’ option the email addresses remain visible to all. ‘Bcc’ hides the recipient’s email addresses from the other recipients. By sending the information to her home Gmail, Angie is in breach of the organisation's policies and procedures and puts the information outside the security of the organisation, making it potentially accessible from unsecured devices and by unauthorised individuals.

displayTitle:
Using the system securely

Email and internet dos and don’ts
body:
We’ve seen from Angie’s experience that there can be pitfalls when using emails and the internet.

Here are some good guidlines which you should follow.
instruction: Select each option to see more.

items.feedbackbody:
DosYou’re responsible for what you send and what you read, and there are some very important rules that you should follow to make sure you stay within the law and keep to the organisation’s policies and procedures.

The organisation could inspect emails and monitor internet use to make sure that the system is not being used inappropriately.

Select the Rules button to see our rules about what you must always do when you’re using email and the internet.

casestudy.casestudybody:
Rules you must follow

Email

  • Make sure you’re sending emails to the correct person before you press ‘Send’. (Be extra careful if you use the ‘autofill’ function.)
  • Make sure your contact details are accurate and up-to-date.
  • Use the Out of Office Assistant to let people know when you’re not available, and provide alternative contact details wherever possible.
  • When sending emails to a group of individuals use the ‘Bcc’, function and if you use a pre-existing email group make sure the contact list is correct.


Internet

  • When using the internet don’t search unlawful, malicious or pornographic sites.
  • Seek approval for access to unsuitable/blocked sites from either your manager, Information Governance Officer, or IT service.
  • If you use Facebook, Twitter or other social media networks you should read and follow any organisational social networking guidance and get a manager’s permission before you do.

items.feedbackbody:
Don’tsYou should take responsibility for your part in keeping information secure when you’re using email or the internet at work. Breaches of security are very serious and could result in disciplinary action.

However, if you do something accidentally that could cause sensitive information to become accessible, such as send an email to the wrong person, or leave confidential papers in an open space, you should tell a manager and your Information Governance Officer immediately.

Select the Rules button to see our rules about what you must never do when you’re using email and the internet.

casestudy.casestudybody:
Things you must never do

  • Send emails that could be considered offensive in any way.
  • Disclose personal, sensitive or confidential information where it’s not appropriate.
  • Alter a message or attachment created by someone else without getting their permission.
  • Send confidential or sensitive information via an unsecure system, for example from your work PC to your home PC.
  • Use the auto-forward function.
  • Use your access to the organisation’s systems for personal use, for example looking up information about family or friends.

instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
Using the system securely

The cyber security threat

Cybercrime is now a serious national and international threat taken as seriously by government as terrorism and war. Hackers are increasingly targeting individuals and large organisations such as local authorities in ever more sophisticated ways, so it’s really important to be vigilant. If in doubt you should speak to your manager, Information Governance Officer and IT.

Cybercrime can take the form of malware to infect computers and phishing using malicious e-mails/attachments, or spear phishing or vishing. You could also be the victim of social engineering, where someone tries to gain your confidence to obtain information they shouldn’t have, or baiting where a physical device, such as a memory stick which is infected with malware, is left lying around for someone to find and load on to their computer.

The important thing to remember is that if you suspect that a cybercrime is being attempted (for example you receive an e-mail with just a link and no accompanying text, or an e-mail looks suspicious and you don’t recognise the sender), inform IT or your equivalent technical support straight away.

Don’t forget that your own personal information is potentially at risk as well. You need to protect yourself at home as well as at work from cybercrime.

Useful information about staying safe online can be found on the National cyber security centre website.

Using the system securely

Inviting trouble

The key to avoiding cybercrime is to remain vigilant at all times when you’re online.

Let’s look at Ravi’s experience when he arrives at work early to write an important report.

Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body: Connecting a personal deviceRavi connects his personal mobile phone to his computer to copy personal pictures to the organisations network drive

Checking his emailsRavi receives an email suggesting his online activity has been tracked and that his passwords have been stolen, the email goes on to threaten Ravi with sending copies of web-cam footage to all of his address book. The attacker asks for onea href='javascript:void(0);' class='glossary' title='bitcoin'> bitcoin to stop the attack. Frightened, Ravi pays the bitcoin using the link provided. He does not tell anyone as he is embarrassed.

A phone call from DISLater that morning Ravi receives a phone call from the IT service desk telling him that there’s a problem with the system and that they need to check the details of people that are currently online.

They ask him for his user name and he tells them. He then offers his password but is told that he should never let anybody else know his password.

instruction: Select the two correct statements. Then select Submit.
instructionFinal: Select Next to continue or the menu icon to return to the menu.
body:
Using the system securely

What went wrong?

Think about the situations Ravi found himself in. Consider his actions and decide which of these statements are correct.

_items.text: Ravi’s pictures are safe on the network drive and will never be viewed by anyone else.
Policy supports storing personal documents on the network drive.
Ravi should have contacted the IT service desk to report the threatening email.
Ravi was wrong to provide his log-on and password.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. The organisation’s scanning systems could automatically check all files for malicious and suspicious file types, personal files should never be downloaded on the organisations network. Network drives are often shared and privacy cannot be guaranteed. In terms of the threatening email, the IT service desk can advise on these issues and reassure when there is nothing to be concerned about. It’s important that the IT specialists are made aware of current phishing campaigns to enable them to improve the controls in place to protect you. The IT service desk will never ask you for your password. They may ask you for you payroll number or username.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. The organisation’s scanning systems could automatically check all files for malicious and suspicious file types, personal files should never be downloaded on the organisations network. Network drives are often shared and privacy cannot be guaranteed. In terms of the threatening email, the IT service desk can advise on these issues and reassure when there is nothing to be concerned about. It’s important that the IT specialists are made aware of current phishing campaigns to enable them to improve the controls in place to protect you. The IT service desk will never ask you for your password. They may ask you for you payroll number or username.

body:
Away from the office

What could go wrong?

When you’re working away from the office there are additional things you must consider to keep information secure. Let’s have a look at a scenario to see what some of these are.

Select the arrow buttons to see the case study.

_items.body: Ameera and Finley are unable to find a meeting space at work and hold their work meeting at a busy local cafe.
Ameera uses her work laptop to join the cafes free Wi-Fi, she immediately instigates the VPN (virtual private network) before browsing the internet.
The meeting requires Ameera to capture personal information on her work laptop and in her note book. She keeps her notebook in her laptop bag.

instruction: Select the correct answer. Then select Submit.
body:
Away from the office

What could go wrong?

Think about the situation and following statements.Partially Correct (Intermediate Answer)

Remember on public networks internet browsing could be viewed including any passwords you may use. Data protection requires further protective procedures.

Think about the situation and following statements.

_items.text: Ameera and Finley should always use the VPN when working on public Wi-Fi.
It’s ok to use the free Wi-Fi to access the intranet, it’s secure.
Ameera and Finley are fine to discuss work matters and record personal details using their work notebooks and laptops in a busy cafe, so long as they are discreet.

_feedback.correct:
Correct (Answer valuation: Good)

Well done, that’s right.

The VPN protects the data you are working on, without VPN your internet browsing could be viewed including any passwords you may use (remember this when using your laptop for non-work purposes too).

Personal matters should not be discussed in a public area where other people can potentially hear.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect  (Answer valuation: Poor)

That’s not right.

The VPN protects the data you are working on, without VPN your internet browsing could be viewed including any passwords you may use (remember this when using your laptop for non-work purposes too).

Personal matters should not be discussed in a public area where other people can potentially hear.

body:
Away from the office

What could go wrong?

Let’s have a look at another scenario involving Ameera to see what else you need to consider to keep information secure when working away from the office.

Select the arrow buttons to see the case study.

_items.body: Further to meeting with Finley, Ameera heads home, placing her notebook and laptop together in her work bag, in her car. .
Ameera recently changed her password and has written it in her notebook to remind herself.
Later that night Ameera’s car is stolen and her laptop bag is still in the car with the laptop and works phone.

instruction: Select the correct answer. Then select Submit.
body:
Away from the office

What could go wrong?

The next day Ameera realises that her car was stolen with her laptop bag and notebook. What would have been the best thing for Ameera to do?Partially Correct (Intermediate Answer)

Though Ameera could not prevent the theft of her car, is there anything she should or should not have done to protect the organisation’s information?

_items.text: Ameera should have stored her laptop bag securely inside her house and out of sight.
There is nothing Ameera could have done to prevent the incident, her car was locked and it was unfortunate that it was stolen.
It was OK for Ameera to make a note of her password and store it in her notebook alongside her laptop, she has so many passwords to remember.

_feedback.correct:
Correct (Answer valuation: Good)

Well done, that’s right

Ameera should have stored her laptop securely out of sight in her house and not in the car, She also needs to let her manager know straight away because if this results in a risk to the rights of the individual(s) concerned then the organisation only has 72 hours to report it to the ICO.

Also, if it’s likely to result in a high risk situation then the individual(s) concerned must be informed.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect (Answer valuation: Poor)

That’s not right.

Ameera should have stored her laptop securely out of sight in her house and not in the car, She also needs to let her manager know straight away because if this results in a risk to the rights of the individual(s) concerned then the organisation only has 72 hours to report it to the ICO.

Also, if it’s likely to result in a high risk situation then the individual(s) concerned must be informed.

title: Introduction
instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
Feedback

What could go wrong?

Well done, you got both questions right.

You should always log on to the VPN when using your organisations laptop and you should always report a suspected security breach straight away because if this results in a serious information security breach then you only have 72 hours to report it to the ICO.

You’re not completely clear on this, you only got one of the questions right. You should always report a suspected security breach straight away because if this results in a serious information security breach you only have 72 hours to report it to the ICO.

That’s not right, you got both questions wrong. You should always report a suspected security breach straight away so that immediate steps can be taken to prevent the issue possibly getting worse; in addition there is only a 72 hour window in which to report it.

instruction: Select each tab to see more.
instructionFinal: Select Next to continue or the menu icon to return to the menu.
body:
Away from the office

Working away from the office

You’ve seen some important points that you should think about if you work away from your primary office. There are also extra considerations if you sometimes work from home. Here are some principles you should follow.

_items.title: Out and about
_items.body:
You need to be careful with the information you’re carrying with you and you should only take the information you require away from the office.

This means that you shouldn’t take whole files with you, just the minimum amount of paperwork that you need.
It’s important that personal information isn’t viewed, photographed or overheard by anyone in public areas, so you should remain vigilant at all times.

_items.title: Keeping equipment secure
_items.body:
You shouldn’t take laptops and work phone or files with you if you’re going directly to a bar or restaurant after work.

If you’re driving you should always keep laptops and papers out of sight in the car, and if you’re travelling on public transport you should keep them with you at all times.

If you take information home you should ensure it is securely stored away overnight, and not kept in your vehicle.

If information or equipment is lost or stolen report it to DIS on 0113 376 0300, your line manager and the Information Governance Officer as soon as you can.

_items.title: Working remotely
_items.body:
If you work remotely or at home you should return documents to your office as soon as they’re no longer needed.

You should make sure equipment and documents are stored securely overnight – keep your laptop and any documents separate. You should take care that family or friends do not see personal or sensitive information. You must never let anyone other than you see your screen or use your laptop.

instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
Quiz

How much do you know?

Welcome to the Information Governance quiz.

This quiz consists of 7 questions and you’ll need to get at least 4 correct. You’ll be given your score at the end together with instructions on what to do next.

If you don’t get at least 4 questions correct then you’ll be expected to revisit the course before attempting it again.

Good luck!
Which of these statements about how long information can be kept for and how it should be disposed of are true, and which are false?
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: Sensitive information should be disposed of securely using the organisation’s confidential waste arrangements.
Mobile workers are able to dispose of documents at home as long as it’s agreed with their manager first..
If you need to dispose of a memory stick you should contact IT.
The organisation’s retention schedule states that all information should be disposed of every two years.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. The disposal of sensitive information needs to be carried out securely by the organisation via the confidential waste arrangements, and you need to contact IT if you need to dispose of a memory stick. Data Protection law states that personal data should not be kept for longer than is necessary.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. The disposal of sensitive information needs to be carried out securely by the organisation via the confidential waste arrangements, and you need to contact IT if you need to dispose of a memory stick. Data Protection law states that personal data should not be kept for longer than is necessary.

body: Which of these actions reflect appropriate behaviour to prevent cyber-attacks, and which are inappropriate?
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: You must never disclose your computer password to anybody.
If you receive an email that looks suspicious you should delete it; if you have already opened it inform IT straight away.
It’s safe to click on a link to an unknown website if the link is in an email from a colleague you know.
You should immediately report any suspected cyber security incident to your line manager and IT.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. You must stay vigilant by never disclosing your password and report any issues immediately. Never click on links in emails unless you’re absolutely sure they are genuine.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. You must stay vigilant by never disclosing your password and reporting any issues immediately. Never click on links in emails unless you’re absolutely sure they are genuine.

body: Which of these statements about emails and the internet are true and which are false?
instruction: Select the two correct answers. Then select Submit.

_items.text: Emails between you and your team mate about a colleague are private.
It’s OK to look up personal information held by the organisation about your next-door neighbour.
You shouldn’t send personal information to your own personal computer.
It’s Ok to give your password to a colleague when you’re on leave so that they can check your emails.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. Emails about colleagues can still be about their personal data, and you must never use your access to the organisation’s network for personal use. You shouldn’t send personal information to your own personal computer and you must never share your password.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. Emails about colleagues can still be about their personal data, and you must never use your access to the organisation’s network for personal use. You shouldn’t send personal information to your own personal computer and you must never share your password.

body: Which one of the following statements could be the possible consequences of you breaching the data protection law?
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: The organisation could be fined but you wouldn’t be prosecuted.
You could be prosecuted and the organisation could be fined.
The organisation could get a warning but cannot be fined.
Any breach of this law would never result in a criminal record for you.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. The organisation could be fined and you could be prosecuted, fined and receive a criminal record if you deliberately obtained or disclosed personal data (including accessing someone else’s personal data) without the organisation’s consent.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. The organisation could be fined and you could be prosecuted, fined and receive a criminal record if you deliberately obtained or disclosed personal data (including accessing someone else’s personal data) without the organisation’s consent.

body: Which of these statements about creating and storing data are true and which are false?</br>
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: We need to find accurate and important information quickly in order to provide good quality service.
You should have your own filing system on your computer so you can find data quickly if others need it.
You should not save records containing personal information in drives that are accessible to everyone.
It’s not important where you keep information as long as you tell your colleagues where you’ve stored it.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. We do need to find accurate information quickly in order to provide good quality service, so you shouldn’t have your own system, you need to file data in the right place.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That's not right. We do need to find accurate information quickly in order to provide good quality service, so you shouldn’t have your own system, you need to file data in the right place.

instruction: Select the two answers you think are correct. Then select Submit.
body: Which of the following statements about staying safe online are correct?

_items.text: You can open links to any websites as long as the email containing it has come from within the organisation.
If you believe malware has affected your computer you should contact IT and your IG Officer immediately.
The organisation’s system is secure so it’s OK to look at any internet sites.
The organisation can inspect emails and internet use to make sure that the system is not being used inappropriately.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. You always need to be careful when opening links wherever they’ve come from, and you should be careful about the internet sites you visit. If you have any concerns about cyber security you should contact IT and your IG Officer.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. You always need to be careful when opening links wherever they’ve come from, and you should be careful about the internet sites you visit. If you have any concerns about cyber security you should contact IT and your IG Officer.

instruction: Select the three answers you think are correct. Then select Submit.
body: Which of these rules about working away from the office are correct?

_items.text: If you need to take information away from the office you should only take the minimum amount of paperwork that you require.
If you’re travelling on public transport with a laptop you should keep it with you at all times.
You should get your manager’s approval before taking any organisational documents out of the office.
If you work at home you should store your laptop and documents separately and securely overnight.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. You must consider the security of the organisation’s information whenever you’re away from the office. As long as your job requires it you don’t have to get permission from your manager every time you take organisation documents out of the office.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. You must consider the security of the organisation’s information whenever you’re away from the office. As long as your job requires it you don’t have to get permission from your manager every time you take organisation documents out of the office.

instruction: Select Next to continue.
body:
Quiz

How much do you know?

Welcome to the Information Governance quiz.

This quiz consists of 7 questions and you’ll need to get at least 4 correct. You’ll be given your score at the end together with instructions on what to do next.

If you don’t get at least 4 questions correct then you’ll be expected to revisit the course before attempting it again.

Good luck!

instruction: Select the three answers you thik are correct. Then select Submit.
body: Which one of the following passwords would be defined as ‘strong’?

_items.text: You can open links to any websites as long as the email containing it has come from within the organisation.!
If you believe malware has affected your computer you should contact DIS and your IG Officer immediately.
The organisation’s system is secure so it’s OK to look at any internet sites.
The organisation can inspect emails and internet use to make sure that the system is not being used inappropriately.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. You always need to be careful when opening links wherever they’ve come from, and you should be careful about the internet sites you visit. If you have any concerns about cyber security you should contact IT and your IG Officer.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. You always need to be careful when opening links wherever they’ve come from, and you should be careful about the internet sites you visit. If you have any concerns about cyber security you should contact IT and your IG Officer.

body: Which of the following statements about creating and storing information are true and which are false?
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: It’s not important where you keep information as long as you know where to find it.
Good quality information means that you don’t have to do the work twice.
Filing information in the correct place helps others who need it to be able to find it.
It’s not important which drive you keep information on as long as you tell your colleagues where to find it.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. You need to make sure you put information on your computer in the correct drive and it helps others to find it when they need to.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. You need to make sure you put information on your computer in the correct drive and it helps others to find it when they need to.

body: Which of the following statements about the Freedom of Information Act are true and which are false?
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: There is no time limit on how long it takes to deal with a Freedom of Information request.
If you receive a Freedom of Information request from someone outside the organisation you should tell your manager.
You must deal with a Freedom of Information request within 12 months in all cases.
In normal cases the period for dealing with a Freedom of Information request is 20 working days.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. There are set periods for dealing with Freedom of Information requests and in normal cases it’s 20 working days. If you receive a request you should tell your manager.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. There are set periods for dealing with Freedom of Information requests and in normal cases it’s 20 working days. If you receive a request you should tell your manager.

body: Which of the following statements about the possible consequences of the organisation not complying with the General Data Protection Regulation are true and which are false?
instruction: Select the correct answer for each question. Then select Submit.

_items.text: The organisation’s reputation could be damaged.
The organisation can be fined.
The public lose trust in us.
Individuals can’t be prosecuted for breaches of the Act, only organisations.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. There could be damage to the organisation’s reputation, the public would lose trust in us and the organisation could receive a fine for this offence. Individuals can be prosecuted if they deliberately obtain or disclose (including accessing) someone else’s personal data without the organisation’s consent.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. There could be damage to the organisation’s reputation, the public would lose trust in us and the organisation could receive a fine for this offence. Individuals can be prosecuted if they deliberately obtain or disclose (including accessing) someone else’s personal data without the organisation’s consent.

instruction: Select the correct answer. Then select Submit.
body: Which one of the following statements defines how long the organisation can keep or store personal data?

_items.text: There is no time limit.
Only for as long as is necessary; i.e. as dictated by law and/or business needs.
Five years.
Until we decide we don’t need it.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. The organisation can keep personal data only for as long as is necessary.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. The organisation can keep personal data only for as long as is necessary.

instruction: Select the two correct answers. Then select Submit.
body: Which two of the following statements about working away from the office are correct?

_items.text: You should always keep your laptop out of sight in the boot of your car when you’re driving.
It’s OK to keep papers and equipment on the passenger seat as long as you’re in the car.
Documents should be returned to your workplace as soon as they are not needed.
It’s OK to discuss confidential work matters in public as long as you’re discreet.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. You should keep papers and equipment out of sight in the car, and documents must be returned to the workplace as soon as they are no longer needed. You shouldn’t discuss confidential matters in public.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. You should keep papers and equipment out of sight in the car, and documents must be returned to your workplace as soon as they are no longer needed. You shouldn’t discuss confidential matters in public.

instruction: Select the two correct answers. Then select Submit.
body: Which of the following statements about staying safe online are correct?

_items.text: You can open links to any websites as long as the email containing it has come from within the organisation.
If you believe malware has affected your computer you should contact IT and your IG Officer immediately.
The organisation’s system is secure so it’s OK to look at any internet sites.
The organisation can inspect emails and internet use to make sure that the system is not being used inappropriately.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

Well done, that’s right. You always need to be careful when opening links wherever they’ve come from, and you should be careful about the internet sites you visit. If you have any concerns about cyber security you should contact IT and your IG Officer.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

That’s not right. You always need to be careful when opening links wherever they’ve come from, and you should be careful about the internet sites you visit. If you have any concerns about cyber security you should contact IT and your IG Officer.
